learning.meaning: relating directly to the subject being considered; relevant: a pertinent question
very noticeable, important, or famous: She plays a prominent role in the organization.; If something is prominent, it sticks out from a surface or can be seen easily: She has a prominent chin/nose.
the quality of being honest, sincere, and kind in dealing with other people: "We want to help but really donâ€™t know how," she said with surprising candor.
friendly and pleasant: congenial company/surroundings
actively opposing or showing unfriendliness towards something or someone: He's extremely antagonistic towards all critics.
to prevent the plans or efforts of someone or something from being achieved: The continuing civil war is frustrating the efforts of relief agencies.

to make something more beautiful by adding something to it: The ceiling was embellished with flowers and leaves.; [ I or T ] to add or change some details of a story, usually to make it more interesting or exciting: He couldn't resist embellishing the story of his accident a little.
to suddenly release a violent force that cannot be controlled: At worst, nuclear war could be unleashed.
in a state of being upset, nervous, and worried: She was so tired and overwrought that she burst into tears.

extremely determined to act in a particular way and not to change despite what anyone else says: The president remains obdurate on immigration; used to describe a person who refuses to change their mind, or someone or something that is difficult to deal with or change: Union leaders remain obdurate that working conditions and pay improve.
a person who has no home or money and often lives outside; â€‹(of buildings or equipment) not cared for and in bad condition
until now or until a particular time: Mira revealed hitherto unsuspected talents on the dance floor.; Economic aid has been offered to hitherto depressed people.
to make something appear by magic, or as if by magic: In an instant, the magician had conjured (up) a dove from his hat.
to join or become combined: Genes determine how we develop from the moment the sperm fuses with the egg.; The bones of the skull are not properly fused at birth.
to move someone or something to the side or away: Seals can shunt blood away from their skin to maintain body temperature.
(of words and language) connected with meaning: Words are semantic units that convey meaning.
the state of being opaque, or the degree to which something is opaque
having or containing a lot of knowledge that is known by very few people: He's the author of an erudite book on Scottish history.
Menial work is boring, makes you feel tired, and is given a low social value: It's fairly menial work, such as washing dishes and cleaning floors.

[formal] a period of time when an illness is less severe or is not affecting someone: Her cancer has been in remission for several years. ; [uk specialized law] a reduction of the time that a person has to stay in prison: He was given three months' remission for good behaviour.; the fact of being forgiven for breaking religious laws or rules: He believes that redemption is based on remission of sins.
a bowl of ornamental china fruit;
that can be calculated
the fact that there is too little of something: There is a paucity of information on the ingredients of many cosmetics.
a short but complete account of a particular subject, esp. in the form of a book: She put together a compendium of early American furniture.
a formal piece of writing that considers and examines a particular subject: a six-volume treatise on trademark law
a very unpleasant and painful or difficult experience: The hostages' ordeal came to an end when soldiers stormed the building.
the situation when the parts of something fit together in a natural or reasonable way: There was no coherence between the first and the second half of the movie.
the most important or exciting point in a story or situation, especially when this happens near the end: The climax of the air show was a daring flying display.
a short pause in which nothing happens or is said, or a space where something is missing: The company expects to resume production of the vehicle again after a two-month hiatus.
to tell someone what he or she must have or do, or to give as a rule: A secretary of education cannot and should not prescribe the curriculum of the nationâ€™s colleges.

to persuade someone to do something by offering them something pleasant: The adverts entice the customer into buying things they don't really want. One of the enticements of the job is the company car.
to spread through something and be present in every part of it: The smell of detergent and bleach permeated the air.
the state of being dormant (= not active or growing but able to become active later): Warm temperatures bring the seeds out of dormancy.
to come or bring something back to life, health, existence, or use: to revive someone's hopes/confidence/fortunes; My plants revived as soon as I gave them some water.
(IDEA) to start developing: I felt an idea germinating in my head/mind.
to increase a lot and suddenly in number: Small businesses have proliferated in the last ten years.
to laugh or shout insults at someone to show you have no respect for them: The people at the back of the hall jeered (at) the speaker.
If a lawyer appears for someone, he or she acts for and represents the person: Ms Hawley was appearing for the defence.
to be unwilling to do something or to allow something to happen: I balked at the prospect of spending four hours on a train with him.

an extremely cruel, violent, or shocking act: They are on trial for committing atrocities against the civilian population.;  the fact of something being extremely cruel, violent, or shocking: These people are guilty of acts of appalling atrocity (= cruelty).
enjoying and being honest or clear about things connected to life, such as the body and emotions: Some readers may not like his earthy humor.

deceiving people in a clever way in order to get what you want: He's a sly old devil - I wouldn't trust him with my money.;  seeming to know secrets: "You'll find out eventually," said Mary, with a sly smile.
to surprise a person or animal: She startled him when she said hello.
the quality of being open and direct, often in a way that refers to sex and the human body: I like the earthiness of her writing.
to slide without intending to: She slipped on the ice.; to move easily and quietly so you are not noticed, or to move something easily into position: Ben slipped the credit card into the machine.

not polite or socially acceptable; not suitable or acceptable in style: His manners were coarse and vulgar.; rude or offensive, esp. because referring to sex: The movie is rated PG and has a few mildly vulgar jokes.
having a pleasant and flowing sound: a deep mellifluous voice
exciting and slightly shocking, especially because of relating to or suggesting sex: She is trying to create a racier image for herself.
language that refers to sex in a rude but humorous way: good-natured ribaldry
strong belief in a religion that is shown in the way someone lives
often feeling uncomfortable with other people and easily embarrassed: She gave a bashful smile as he complimented her on her work.
the wish to travel far away and to many different places: In July wanderlust takes over the whole nation.
the movement of a lot of people from a place: There has been a mass exodus of workers from the villages to the towns.

(STOP) to lose strength or purpose and stop, or almost stop: The dinner party conversation faltered for a moment.; to move awkwardly as if you might fall: The nurse saw him falter and made him lean on her.
An inaugural speech is the first speech someone gives when starting an important new job: the president's inaugural address to the nation
used to say that someone is strong, brave, determined, and difficult to defeat or frighten: The indomitable Mrs Furlong said she would continue to fight for justice.

a prize, such as a gold or silver cup, that is given to the winner of a competition or race, and often returned after a year to be given to the winner of the competition in the following year: He's an excellent rider, but he's never won a major trophy.
not certain: People say that they produce the best athletes in the world, but I think that's disputable.
to say exactly how something must be or must be done: She agreed to buy the car, but stipulated racing tyres and a turbo-powered engine.
understanding or realizing something: We should be cognizant of the fact that every complaint is not a justified complaint.
not having something or feeling great loss: Alone now and almost penniless, he was bereft of hope.
the typical or highest example of a stated quality, as shown by a particular person or thing: Even now in her sixties, she is the epitome of French elegance.
brought together, combined, or united: We have to be able to speak with a unified voice on this subject.
impossible to persuade, or unwilling to change an opinion or decision: [ + that ] I've told her she should stay at home and rest but she's adamant that she's coming.
connected with a god, or like a god: Some fans seem to regard the players as divine beings.
putting a lot of effort into your work: a conscientious student
the state of feeling very confused because someone or something is impossible to understand: And then, to the audience's mystification, the band suddenly stopped playing.
not having any connection with religion: We live in an increasingly secular society, in which religion has less and less influence on our daily lives.
(PERFORMANCE) [formal] the performance of duties or payment of money that is owed: the discharge of his duties
(used in questions or negatives) possible: What earthly reason can she have for being so rude?
to say that you know nothing about or have no responsibility for something: He disavowed his earlier confession to the police.
wishing to fight or argue: a belligerent person; fighting a war: The belligerent countries are having difficulties funding the war.
the possibility that someone will make mistakes or that something will not work as it should: The play deals with the fallibility of human nature. He spoke frankly about his own fallibility.

to collect large amounts of something and keep it in a safe, often secret, place: During the siege people began hoarding food and supplies.; a large amount of something that someone has saved and hidden: We found a huge hoard of tinned food in the basement.
the act or process of returning something to its earlier good condition or position: The first task following the disaster was the restoration of clean water supplies.
strongly supporting a person, principle, or political party, often without considering or judging the matter very carefully: The audience was very partisan, and refused to listen to her speech.
changing mood or behaviour suddenly and unexpectedly: a capricious child
allowing someone to have or do what they want, especially when this is not good for them: He had been a strict father but was indulgent to/towards his grandchildren.
following the order in which a series of events happened: Give me the dates in chronological order.
seeming to be everywhere: Leather is very much in fashion this season, as is the ubiquitous denim.
to avoid telling the truth or saying exactly what you think: He accused the minister of prevaricating.
having or showing reason and good judgment in making decisions: We should make judicious use of the resources available to us.

to get rid of something or someone that is not wanted or needed: The station has jettisoned educational broadcasts.; to decide not to use an idea or plan: We've had to jettison our trip because of David's accident.; to throw goods, fuel, or equipment from a ship or aircraft to make it lighter: The captain was forced to jettison the cargo and make an emergency landing.

a drawing or a written or spoken description that makes part of someone's appearance or character more noticeable than it really is, or the skill of doing this: [ C ] I saw a wonderful caricature of the president in the newspaper.; to show or describe a person in a ridiculous way: Itâ€™s so easy to caricature politicians.
to express sadness and feeling sorry about something: The poem opens by lamenting (over) the death of a young man.
made angry easily: She's becoming more and more irascible as she grows older.
in a way that shows that you are made angry easily: Their manager often behaves irascibly.
going off and on irregularly: Her breathing is fitful.
